Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Positioning System in GPS-denied Environments using Euclidean TOA Ranging and Linear Matrix Inequalities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Because of the critical needs for scalable data dissemination and efficient spatial query processing for supporting large-scale information systems with mobile users, there is a great demand for accurate positioning of mobile devices. Only with these capabilities, one will be able to develop scalable data dissemination and query evaluation infrastructure for querying, indexing, and routing datasets to support novel mobile applications. These needs will drive customers' willingness to pay for these capabilities. For example, important customers are firemen who will use this technology in a burning building to locate victims trapped in the building using this positioning method that is based on opportunistic communication among the group of firemen and the victim's mobile devices. In this proposal, the I-Corps team introduces new software for accurately determining the positions of mobile devices, even in GPS-denied environments.

The proposed innovative method for positioning does not use special hardware as UWB or ultrasounds transceivers. Instead, the proposed positioning software will run on typical smartphones and laptops. A GPS-denied target node with no position information communicates opportunistically with a number of in-range mobile peer nodes with some positioning capabilities. Data exchanges between the target node and peer nodes are used by the target node to refine its position estimation using three algorithms: Euclidean TOA (Time of Arrival), LMI (Linear Matrix Inequalities) and barycentric algorithms. Using the approximate ranges from the Euclidean TOA method, the LMI and barycentric algorithms are then applied to improve position accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Positioning of mobile devices, such as smartphones, tablets and laptops, is an important problem because many useful mobile applications will be enabled once accurate position information is available. Unfortunately, in GPS-denied environments, positioning is not feasible, e.g. indoor, urban canyons, and tree canopies. Other positioning systems require sophisticated hardware (e.g. UWB, ultrasounds transceiver) that is not cost-effective.  Yet another approach use positions of dedicated infrastructures (e.g. cellular base stations and WLAN access points) which are grossly inaccurate. Popular approaches that use signal strength have been shown to be very inaccurate. Our positioning system instead uses commercial off-the-shelf mobile devices, e.g. smartphones, and does not require special hardware. A GPS-denied target node with no position information communicates opportunistically with a number of in-range mobile peer nodes with some positioning capabilities. Data exchanges between the target node and peer nodes are used by the target node to refine its position estimation using three algorithms: Euclidean TOA (Time of Arrival), LMI (Linear Matrix Inequalities) and barycentric algorithms. Using the approximate ranges from the Euclidean TOA method, the LMI and barycentric algorithms are then applied to improve position accuracy. Our preliminary studies on the performance of this opportunistic localization algorithm in computer simulations show that opportunistic interactions can improve self-localization accuracy, where the position estimation error is about 10% or less. The customers of this technology are mobile device users, e.g. smartphones, spatial information systems, and intelligent cooperative systems, such as intelligent vehicles, that will benefit from this simpler and cost-effective localization technique.

Many new mobile applications will become possible when accurate position information becomes available in many GPS-denied environments, such as indoor and urban canyons. This will spur the development and use of the following mobile applications. U.S. government mandates the U.S. Mobile Alert System that sends alerts regarding public safety emergencies to smartphone users based on their location, including indoor. Mobile applications that also benefit from this technology are scalable data dissemination and efficient spatial query evaluation for large-scale mobile applications, such as traffic control, homeland security, and law enforcement. Vehicle-to-vehicle communication and platoon control systems will also rely on the position information of vehicles even in GPS-denied urban canyons.

The competitive advantage of our software is that it can be easily installed in standard mobile devices and does not use expensive hardware or use the signal strength method which has been shown to be very inaccurate and unreliable. Since our method is novel and substantially different from other methods, we will patent this technique. Our  I-Corps team will introduce the new software for accurately determining the positions of mobile devices even in GPS-denied environments through the establishment of a new startup company. Future revenue will comprise of direct sales and licensing revenue. Through customer discovery, risk assessment and lessons learned, the product research and development will be agilely adapted using evidence-based strategies.

The NSF I-CORPS program provides critical instructive and practical paths to commercialize the academic research into a real world product. The program is structured to teach clearly define and test the hypothesis concerning our product and our customers’ inclination for purchasing them. During the customer discovery process we talked to the customers in person to understand their problems and try to develop our research into a product that will solve those problems. One of the most important factors to be considered during the customer discovery process is that we should not try to sell our product to the customers; instead we should are trying to find their pain points and deduce whether we can develop a product that will alleviate those pain points.
